item.title: NJ Congresswoman Pleads Not Guilty to Obstructing ICE Agents
item.description: US Representative LaMonica McIver pleaded not guilty to federal charges that she interfered with law enforcement outside a 1,000-bed immigration detention facility in Newark, New Jersey.
item.dc:creator: Chris Dolmetsch

media:content.media:description: LaMonica McIver exits the grounds at Delaney Hall, an ICE detention facility, in Newark, New Jersey, on May 9.

item.title: Royal Pomp and Political Flattery Help Sway Trump on NATO Unity
item.description: It was a reception fit for a king.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Flavia Krause-Jackson, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte and US President Donald Trump speak during a family photo before a plenary session of the NATO summit in The Hague, on June 25.

item.title: Trump Says US to Consider More Air-Defense Batteries for Ukraine
item.description: Donald Trump said he will look into sending more Patriot air-defense batteries to Ukraine following “a good” meeting with President Volodymyr Zelenskiy as allies seek more US pressure on Russia to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Andrea Dudik

media:content.media:description: Ukrainan President Volodymyr Zelenskiy during the NATO Summit in The Hague, on June 24.

item.title: How Trump’s Spurning of European Allies Is Transforming NATO
item.description: NATO is trying to reinvent itself just as the military alliance confronts Europe’s deadliest conflict since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Kati Pohjanpalo

media:content.media:description: US President Trump at the 2018 NATO Summit. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: Alberta Premier Warns Carney He Must Act to Quell Separatist Threat
item.description: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith played down concerns that the secession movement in her province will scare away investors, saying it’s up to the government of Mark Carney to prove Canada can be a more attractive place for capital.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Orland

media:content.media:description: Danielle Smith, Alberta's premier, during an interview in Calgary, Alberta, Canada, on Monday, June 23, 2025. Smith expects a private-sector firm to propose a new oil pipeline to the British Columbia coast within weeks in a bid to become one of the first entrants on the Canadian government's list of nationally important projects.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Double Spanish Tariffs Over NATO Spending
item.description: President Donald Trump assailed Spain for refusing to agree to new defense spending targets adopted by NATO and suggested the country could be penalized by facing tariffs twice as high from the US.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Josh Wingrove

item.title: AI Titans Flex Clout to Leverage Tax Bill to Override State Laws
item.description: Powerful Silicon Valley leaders are throwing their weight behind the tech industry’s drive to use Donald Trump’s tax bill to sweep away state regulations on artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Oma Seddiq

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 23, 2025. President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending agenda is nearing a climactic vote in the Senate this week in the wake of air strikes on Iran, which risk embroiling the US in a prolonged Middle East conflict.

item.title: Carney Says Canada Met With European Suppliers Amid F-35 Review
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said he met with European defense suppliers about jets and submarines, and expects to conclude a review of a major contract for Lockheed Martin Corp. F-35 jets as soon as this summer.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: Canada's prime minister Mark Carney speaks during a news conference at the NATO summit in The Hague, on June 25.

item.title: Dutch Far-Right Leader Courts President Trump at NATO Summit
item.description: Dutch far-right leader Geert Wilders met with Donald Trump on the sidelines of the NATO Summit in The Hague, where they discussed “the need for tougher immigration laws,” Wilders said in a post on X.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Hughes-Morgan, Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Geert Wilders

item.title: Middle East War Reset Dollar’s Inverse Link to Stocks, Goldman Says
item.description: This month’s geopolitical tension focused on the Middle East is re-establishing the dollar’s traditional inverse relationship with risk assets, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
item.dc:creator: Carter Johnson

item.title: Clashes Between Kenya Police, Protesters Leave Three Dead
item.description: Three people are reported to have died in clashes between the police and crowds of people who gathered Wednesday to mark the first anniversary of anti-government demonstrations in which dozens were killed.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: A man waves a Kenyan flag as demonstrators march in downtown Nairobi on June 25. Photographer: LUIS TATO/AFP

item.title: Trump Says US and Iran to Talk Next Week, Mideast War Is ‘Over’
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US would hold a meeting with Iran next week but cast doubt on the need for a diplomatic agreement, citing the damage that American bombing had done to its key nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference at the NATO summit in The Hague, on June 25.

item.title: Trump Says Three or Four People on List to Replace Fed’s Powell
item.description: President Donald Trump said he has three or four people in mind to succeed Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell when his term expires next year.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Europe Wins Over Trump on Defense With NATO Spending Boost
item.description: NATO leaders agreed to increase defense spending to 5% of GDP and renewed their “ironclad commitment” to mutual security in an historic move to push back against an increasingly belligerent Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Michael Nienaber, Stephanie Lai

item.title: California Schools Risk DC Funding Cuts on Transgender Athlete Debate
item.description: Public school funding in California is at risk after the US Education Department found that the state is violating rules protecting female athletes from unfair competition and unsafe situations “by allowing males in girls’ sports and intimate spaces.”
item.dc:creator: Erin Hudson

item.title: Erdogan Tells Macron to Include Turkey in Europe’s Defense Plans
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan urged French leader Emmanuel Macron to involve non-EU allies like Turkey in shaping Europe’s new security architecture.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: A Eurosam Samp/T NG radar system at the Paris Air Show. Photographer: Matthieu Rondel/Bloomberg

item.title: Finnish Leader Urges Calm Amid Russian Buildup Near Border
item.description: Finland’s President Alexander Stubb said his nation remains “calm and collected” amid reports of Russian troop buildup near the NATO member’s border.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Crook, Ott Ummelas

media:content.media:description: Finland's President Alexander Stubb Photographer: Ludovic Marin/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Congo Signs Digital-Identification Deal With Singapore’s Trident
item.description: Democratic Republic of Congo signed an agreement with Trident Digital Tech Holdings Ltd. of Singapore to develop a national digital identity and e-government system.
item.dc:creator: Michael J Kavanagh

media:content.media:description: Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo

item.title: Trump Administration Urges Appeals Court to Back Tariff Power
item.description: The Trump administration defended the president’s power to impose sweeping global tariffs, arguing to a federal appeals court that it should overturn a decision finding the levies unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: A container ship leaves the Port of Newark in Elizabeth, New Jersey.

item.title: UK to Buy Nuclear-Capable F-35s Amid Risk of Trump Pullback
item.description: The UK will buy at least a dozen new US-made F-35 fighter jets capable of carrying nuclear weapons, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks to curry favor with President Donald Trump while hedging against a pull-back in American security support.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: A US Air Force Lockheed Martin F-35A Lightning II military jet air display at the Paris Air Show in Paris, France, on Monday, June 16, 2025. The 55th Paris Air Show runs 16-20 June at Le Bourget airport.

item.title: Iran Says Nuclear Facilities ‘Badly Damaged’ by US Strikes
item.description: Iran said its nuclear installations were “badly damaged” by US airstrikes, the first such comments by Tehran as debate grows over how much the bombardment managed to dent the Islamic Republic’s atomic program.
item.dc:creator: Dana Khraiche

media:content.media:description: The Isfahan Nuclear Technology and Research Center after US strikes, on June 22. Source: Satellite image ©2025 Maxar Technologies

item.title: Swiss Admit Spat With US on Fighter Jet Price, Still Want F-35A
item.description: Switzerland and the US are at odds on the agreed price for three dozen F-35A fighter jets the country wants to buy from Lockheed Martin Corp., adding to existing tensions over US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: An F-35A fighter jet.

item.title: Trump-Inspired ‘Israel Edition’ Coin Pushed in Iran Conflict
item.description: The email hit inboxes on Monday, a tense period after US attacks against Iranian nuclear sites, but before President Donald Trump announced a cease-fire in the war between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Annie Massa

media:content.media:description: An archived version of the God Bless The USA Bible webpage offering the Trump Coin Israel Edition.

item.title: Early Report Suggests US Strikes Only Set Back Iran Nuclear Program by Months
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — A U.S. intelligence report suggests that Iran’s nuclear program has been set back only a few months after U.S. strikes and was not “completely and fully obliterated” as President Donald Trump has said, according to two people familiar with the early assessment.

media:content.media:description: Building damage across the Isfahan nuclear technology center in Iran on June 22.

item.title: Trump Policies Will Cut Deficits Up to $11 Trillion, White House Economist Says
item.description: President Donald Trump’s policies will reduce US fiscal deficits by up to $11 trillion over the coming decade, according to the White House’s chief economist — a projection that defies analysts who say government debt is poised to climb to record highs in coming years.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers Stephen Miran

item.title: ‘Daddy’ Trump Can't Be Trusted to Love NATO
item.description: Unrealistic defense spending targets won’t make the transatlantic alliance healthier.
item.dc:creator: Lionel Laurent

media:content.media:description: Dick Schoof, Netherlands's prime minister, left, US President Donald Trump, center, and Mark Rutte, secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), during the NATO summit in The Hague, Netherlands, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. The NATO leaders are meeting against the backdrop of heightened tensions in the Middle East.

item.title: Trade Deals Could Eliminate Need for ‘Revenge Tax’, Hassett Says
item.description: Donald Trump’s top economic adviser on Wednesday said the administration is pushing US trading partners to move swiftly on deals that make the “revenge tax” included in the president’s cornerstone legislation unnecessary.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Lauren Vella

media:content.media:description: Kevin Hassett, director of the National Economic Council, speaks to members of the media following a television interview outside the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. Hassett told CNBC “we’ll probably see a few more deals, even this week,” with India being among the countries that are close to the finish line when it comes to securing a deal.

item.title: Trump Rejects Intel Assessment, Says Iran Atomic Sites Destroyed
item.description: US President Donald Trump disputed an intelligence report that found the airstrikes he ordered on Iran had only a limited impact on its nuclear program, even though the assessment came from the Pentagon.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio, Alex Wickham, Natalia Drozdiak

item.title: Trump Offers Backing to NATO Defense Pact: ‘I Stand With It’
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he stood behind NATO’s mutual defense obligations after a historic vote by its members to raise their defense spending to 5% of GDP, offering a commitment that will bolster anxious European allies.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during the NATO summit in The Hague, on June 25.

item.title: Swiss Are Still Holding Out for a US Trade Deal Before July 9
item.description: The Swiss government is still hoping to clinch a trade deal with the US before Donald Trump’s July 9 deadline, but otherwise expects tariffs to remain at the current 10% level if negotiations continue further.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: Paradeplatz in Zurich. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg
